awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Quantifying performance in animals exposed to predictable and unpredictable variation in multiple environmental factors
awd_abstract_narration:
For most species, we cannot say with certainty if variable temperatures that come with extreme events influence their performance. Using an efficient experimental design, PIs Denny and Dowd will take advantage of the unique life history of the tide-pool copepod Tigriopus californicus to quantify how realistic, simultaneous variation in multiple stressors (temperature, salinity, and the concentrations of oxygen and carbon dioxide) interacts with the animal's physiology to affect its ability to survive and reproduce. Because Tigriopus reproduces rapidly and commonly encounters rapid environmental shifts, it can serve as a model organism for experiments with multiple stressors. Insights from these measurements will enhance our ability to predict the biological and ecological effects of variation in temperature. Other impacts of this research will include the inquiry-based training of undergraduate students, including summer research internships for historically underserved groups; a Postdoctoral Mentoring Plan to prepare a recent doctoral graduate for all aspects of a faculty position at a primarily undergraduate institution, a position that involves a suite of responsibilities, opportunities, and challenges different from those at research-oriented universities; and the development of a portable experimental module designed to introduce underserved K-12 students to ecological physiology by measuring aspects of Tigriopus's life cycle. 

Organisms' abilities to perform the tasks necessary to survive and reproduce dictate species' success or failure, but environmental effects on performance are potentially complex. Biologists often account for organism-environment interactions by measuring individual performance at each of a series of constant levels of a single variable, thereby constructing a performance curve. For example, by taking into account the effects of nonlinear averaging (Jensen's inequality), thermal performance curves constructed under static conditions have been used to forecast biological consequences of changes in temperature mean and variance. However, this mathematical approach overlooks several important factors: (1) Compensatory physiological mechanisms may modify the strictly mathematical predictions of performance. For example, brief exposure to stressful temperatures can prime physiology for future events. (2) Environmental variation in nature is often unpredictable, particularly when rare, extreme events are considered. However, this unpredictability only rarely has been considered empirically. (3) The response to variation in one environmental factor may depend on patterns of variation of other stressors. The results of these interactions could be synergistic or antagonistic depending on the underlying physiology. Furthermore, variation can have disparate effects on instantaneous vs. lifetime-integrative performance metrics. By using a new model species and a novel, efficient experimental design, this project explicitly addresses these factors to develop a more robust, environmentally relevant approach to quantifying performance in a variable, unpredictable, and changing world.

por.por_cntn:
Animals’ performance is impacted by the physical environment, which is both continuously fluctuating and rapidly changing. Climate projections indicate that in the near future there will be shifts in both the mean and temporal variability of environmental conditions, and that novel conditions will be encountered. These novel conditions will challenge animal’s ability to cope, yet for most species our understanding of the physiological consequences of even present-day environmental variation within an organism’s lifetime is restricted to a few specific scenarios. In general, we cannot say whether it is shifts in the mean, shifts in variation around that mean, shifts in the timing or intensity of extreme events, or interactions among multiple factors that are most likely to alter organismal performance. To address these uncertainties, we used the splash-pool copepod Tigriopus californicus as a model system to quantify how simultaneous variation in important environmental factors interacts with physiology to affect ecologically relevant aspects of organismal performance.

We documented in great detail the temporal patterns of environmental variation in Tigriopus’s splash-pool habitat and used these field measurements (including extremes of salinity and temperature) to design subsequent physiological laboratory studies for two populations of Tigriopus in California and Washington State. The physical environment encountered by Tigriopus is extraordinarily variable and highly unpredictable. The seawater that occasionally replenished one experimental splash pool has a salinity of 35 parts per thousand (ppt), but salinity in the pool varied from 8 to 190 ppt. Temperatures in that pool ranged from 11oC to 36oC, often varying by more than 20oC in a day. Oxygen levels varied from less than 20% saturation before dawn to nearly 300% saturation in mid-afternoon, leading to a positive correlation in nature between oxygen levels and body temperatures. We analyzed an extensive time series of pool temperature and salinity in detail. While predictable daily and seasonal fluctuations were evident, variation around those fluctuations was such that stressful temperatures and salinities could not be predicted more than 2-3 days in advance, giving Tigriopus’s physiology scant time to adjust. However, while temperature and salinity were individually unpredictable, they tended to vary together. For salinities greater than 25 ppt, if daily maximum temperature is high, salinity also tended to be high.

Our physiological experiments addressed the consequences of these covarying factors, first exploring the relationship between salinity and heat tolerance. The high-temperature tolerance of freshly-collected California copepods increased dramatically with increasing salinity, ranging from 33.7oC at 8 ppt to a peak of 41.2oC at 130 ppt. This relationship was mirrored in the Washington population, albeit with a lower absolute effect of salinity on heat tolerance. The response of heat tolerance to salinity is rapid and was reproduced in the laboratory within 1-2 hours following acute salinity transfers.

We hypothesize that the correlation between salinity and heat tolerance is due to the manner in which Tigriopus copes with elevated salinity by introducing a small osmolyte—the amino acid proline—into its cells. Fortuitously, proline is capable of stabilizing proteins at high temperature. Thus, we theorize that by maintaining an internal solute concentration equal to that of its surroundings, Tigriopus is rapidly and inherently primed to cope with high temperatures. Follow-up experiments are exploring this hypothesis, which runs counter to intuitive notions that two stressors would be worse than one. In a separate study we explored the relationship between heat tolerance and oxygen levels. Contrary to another prevailing hypothesis, environmentally realistic levels of dissolved oxygen had no effect on copepods’ heat tolerance.

To enable these and other experiments, we developed novel research infrastructure and methods to manipulate oxygen, temperature, and pH levels simultaneously and in controlled fashion in the laboratory, and to then quantify effects of these parameters on copepod behavior (swimming activity and oxygen/temperature preference) and physiology (including metabolic rates).

Our data highlight the importance of explicitly testing the predicted consequences of co-varying environmental stressors, the necessity for exploring these consequences in the context of the variation organisms actually experience in nature, and ultimately the need to better understand underlying mechanisms of how multiple stressors interact. Measurements of thermal tolerance in traditional, simplified laboratory experimental protocols could not have predicted how copepod’s physiology would adjust to this sort of realistic environmental variation. By contrast, in this work, the combination of long-term field records and measurements of thermal tolerance provided novel and important insight and new hypotheses that must be tested further. Our findings provide guidance for further research into the biochemical and cellular basis for the interactions between multiple environmental factors, ultimately permitting biologists to move from seemingly idiosyncratic observations to mechanistic predictions.

Broader Impacts of this work primarily involved training of a broad and diverse set of junior scientists, including two postdoctoral researchers, five graduate students, and 16 undergraduate students. In addition, Denny collaborated with the Ocean Discovery Institute (San Diego) to develop K-12 curriculum.
